This is the cross beam set of tudor external corner tiles. I've made substantial changes to how I'm doing external tudor tiles that I am in the process of backporting to the prior external tudor tiles. More on what changed below.

The other sets are here:

  • Basic (This set)
  • Set 1: Diagonals based on the basic set.
  • Cross Beams
  • [Set 2](): Diagonals based on the cross beam set. (still to be published)

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

I've been working on an inn for some time as many of you know. Using cut-stone and tudor tiles for the first floor, and external tudor tiles for the second floor. What I discovered when I started stacking them is that well, the bases of the tudor tiles frankly look like crap when stacked on as a second level. I did a lot of considering about what I wanted to do, and this set is the result. On the exterior, the stucco and beams now all run all the way to the base, and the base itself on the external facing portion now has a wood texture.

You can see the effect below.

New approach to tudor external tiles Here's the comparison with the old style as a second story
• 9/14/2016 - All files repaired in netfabb and reuploaded.

Update 1: I added a cooling fan to the extruder and finally got the Z probe calibrated and working as expected. I have the new controller and firmware working and I am running my first "real" print job tonight.

When the Solidoodle company went out of business, I had to make a lot of replacement parts. Right after I purchased it, something would break. I'd fix that. Then something else would break and I'd fix that. This went on for about a year. One of the chief issues was the print volume was reduced due to fans and table alignment. The second issue was warp-age caused by the 100 x 100mm pad under the aluminum bed.

I modified the printer to have a bowden extruder system, a 200mmx200mm heated bed. I moved the controller board to the outside and added a heated bed controller. This allowed me to reduce the number of fans and increase the print volume where it needed to be.

I also changed the firmware to the new Marlin firmware and calibrated it. I will post the firmware and files shortly.

Work in Progress:
Lately, the controller board has been freezing for no reason I can find. I purchased a $50 MKS Gen 1.4 (Ramps 1.4) controller and graphic LCD. I am waiting on the proper connectors to wire that in as a replacement. It does allow dual extruders, so I am considering this modification as well.

description.header: Phase I - Bowden Extruder and Lawsy Carriages
description.text:
Changing the extruder to E3D V6 and Bowden system.

In the redesign, I have gone through several incremental design changes. Initially, I just added the E3D extruder with a bowden system. That lasted about 1 spool and the X-Carriage failed. After several redesigns using other people's components, I decided to create my own mounting system to accommodate a Z-Probe. This design will probably evolve when I have more time.

If necessary, upgrade to the Lawsy X-Carriage assembly.

Lawsy carriage system; and X-Mod (You will need the X-Mod for a solidoodle 4 for the X-Endstop.

Advice:

  1. Print several and get additional bearings and rods. That way you can swap the X-Carriage when it fails more easily.

  2. Use a small gear puller to remove rods from X-Carriage. I used a plumbers extractor for faucets because it is more flexible (and more than once forgot to put the bearing on first).

Lawsy - X Mod
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:682970

Solidoodle Replacement Carriages
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:104059

Parts Required for the modification (non-3d printed)

Hotend J-head All Metal Wade E3D V6 Direct extruder
http://www.ebay.com/itm/Hotend-J-head-All-Metal-Wade-E3D-V6-Direct-extruder-For-Makerbot-Reprap-printer-/131649256083?var=&hash=item1ea6e83a93:m:meGWYolNxeWb_ZPs4EVJPfA

12pcs LM8UU 8mm Linear Ball Bearing Bushing new
http://www.ebay.com/itm/12pcs-LM8UU-8mm-Linear-Ball-Bearing-Bushing-new-/371674274765?hash=item5689835bcd:g:RZ0AAOSwbYZXeyjB

I maintain a stock of M3 and M4 screws, nuts and washers. (Actual mileage may vary) It is recommended that you have an assortment of sizes. (When I have time, I will count and provide a BOM for them).

UPDATE: Check out the newer version of this file that lets you select from all the Canadian Provinces and Territories (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1781423)

Customizable Ontario (Canada) license plate.

This is part of a car costume (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1770501) and the default size is 120mm x 50mm.

This file uses the Windows Font "Univers 57 Condensed". I have made this a setting if your PC doesn't have the font or you are using customizer it should switch to a default font.

I used a blue sharpie marker to colour the letters.

I used Inkscape and a plugin called paths2openscad (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25036) to convert a blank plate (jpg) to an SCAD file then added the text. It should be easy to duplicate it for another province or state.

UPDATE: I added a variable to squish the text because if the wrong font file is missing it runs off the plate.

This is a bed for your Kindle Fire. Of corse it can easily cradle the iPad as well as the iPhone.
Print using your favorite 3d printer. This model can be resized to fit any device your printer is capable of printing.

"Dress like a car" - anonymous

I used battery tea lights for the headlights and tail lights. I also drilled a few small holes in the side of the fender so I could stitch the whole costume onto a matching t-shirt.

Customizable Canadian License Plates (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1781423).
Customizable American License Plates (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1800070)

Unfortunately I started this project in AutoCAD, I envisioned a more complex blend for the tail lights so those files are dwg format but the rest of the design is SCAD. Eventually I will convert them so the whole costume is SCAD.

How I designed this?

I first started with the fenders. I drew simple ellipses in AutoCAD and revolved them I then cut the ends of and shelled the whole thing and extruded a large circle for the shoulders.

I printed them to make sure it ll looked good and used the printed model to design the remaining car parts.

After the fenders were complete I moved on to the VW medallion and license plate. This was easier then I though it wold be. I downloaded pictures of a VW logo and using Inkscape and Inkscape to SCAD plugin was able to make a simple medallion I then added a square hanging loop.

You can read all about the license plate here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1770479

print_settings.Notes:: If you are going to be JBwelding in a piece of tungsten wire I reccomend printing at a larger layer height (0.2 or 0.25) to give a lot of 'grip' to the epoxy. I bent the wire into a J shape to keep the wire from ever pulling out.

description.text:
This little handle will hold the tiny drills you can get online for cleaning out a clogged nozzle. You can also get some tiny tungsten wire and JBweld it into this handle for really small extruders.

If using ABS, drill using a 1/8" drill and press-fit the shank into the handle. It should be quite tight. Add a drop of sugerglue if its too loose.

If using PLA or PETG you won't be able to drill, but the print is fast enough that you can scale up by 2 or 3% until you find a place where the fit is snug.

Enjoy!!

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Print at 0.1mm layer height and 3 perimeters. Infill is kind of up to you. I printed with PETG and no brim, but you might find a brim to be necessary depending on your printer.

If you are going to be JBwelding in a piece of tungsten wire I reccomend printing at a larger layer height (0.2 or 0.25) to give a lot of 'grip' to the epoxy. I bent the wire into a J shape to keep the wire from ever pulling out.

title: Precision Adjustable Z Endstop Holder and Constraint

description.text:
A precision adjustable optical endstop holder for Prusa printers, with an integrated Z screw constraint bearing.
I got frustrated with trying to adjust my Z axis endstop by sliding the clamp up and down the smooth rail, and found that the available designs for adjustable clamps wouldn't work for me, for one reason or another.

1) Print. 2) Trim off the support inside the bottom nut trap. 3) Ream out the inside of the Endstop Mount/Glide's M8 hole, so that it runs smoothly up and down your Z axis smooth rod.
Â Â Â Â Note: I've found that the knurled end of a narrow X-Acto knife handle (with the blade removed) is the perfect size for reaming out M8 holes. 4) Install a 608 bearing into the bearing cup. 5) Attach an optical endstop to the glide, using 2 M3 X 25mm socket cap bolts and nylock nuts. 6) Optionally, run an M8 or 5/16 nut partway up your Z axis screw. This nut will be used to secure the top of the constraint bearing. 7) Assemble parts onto the smooth rod as follows (top to bottom):
Â Â Â Â a) Glide/Endstop mount.
Â Â Â Â b) 3/8" I.D. x 51/64" spring.
Â Â Â Â c) Clamp/Bearing mount. Â Â Â Â Note: you'll have to loosen your smooth rod, and slide it up out of its lower clamp, then re-affix it once the parts are in place. 8) Attach the Clamp/Bearing mount loosely to the smooth rod using 2 M3 X 20mm socket cap bolts and nylock nuts. 9) Assemble the adjustment bolt onto the assembly as follows (top to bottom):
Â Â Â Â a) M4 x 40mm socket cap bolt.
Â Â Â Â b) M4 washer
Â Â Â Â c) Glide/Endstop mount.
Â Â Â Â d) 11/64" I.D. x 5/8" spring.
Â Â Â Â e) Clamp/Bearing mount.
Â Â Â Â f) M4 nylock nut. 10) Move the clamp into its final position, and tighten the clamp bolts. 11) Optionally, secure the constraint bearing to the Z axis screw using 2 M8 or 5/16 nuts. Vitamins: 2x - M3 x 25mm socket cap bolt.
2x - M3 x 20mm socket cap bolt.
4x - M3 nylock nut.
4x - M3 washer.
1x - M4 x 40mm socket cap bolt.
1x - M4 nylock nut.
1x - M4 washer.
1x - 3/8" I.D. x 51/64" spring.
1x - 11/64" I.D. x 5/8" spring.
1x - Optical endstop. I used a MakerBot endstop, but any optical endstop with 19mm mounting hole spacing should work. Note: If you look carefully at the photo, you'll see that I didn't use #6/32 bolts and nylock nuts on mine, instead of M3, simply because that's what I had on hand. The .stl provided is sized for M3 bolts. Note: The springs I used came from a spring assortment kit sold by Home Depot - Everbilt #471864.

author: hastla

description.text:
The inspiration here is threefold:
  • After seeing the awesome sculptural work being done on the pet monster contest, I knew I wanted to try my hand at organic modeling and I wanted a way a cool way to incorporate it into a 3D print. I decided to prototype a base to work off of in the future.
  • I've been thinking about how traditional crafts can be augmented with 3D printing. I came across an article on marionettes from a 1936 Popular Science article with some great info. http://tinyurl.com/6reet4u
  • The size of the new Replicator platform! Suddenly a 16" tall marionette is doable without a million pieces.
    • I wanted a puppet that didn't require additional hardware, and that assembled without a lot of fuss. I tried variations of both Zomboe's snake http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4743 and Landru's springamathing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12053 as a replacement for traditional cloth hinges. At this point, the pieces I've prototyped on my thing-o-matic don't have nearly enough movement to serve as a marionette, and thinner renditions have been too fragile. But, I have a start of something interesting. I'm not sure if I'll continue to spend time on an all-plastic solution, or look for ways to make tyvek cloth hinges with plastic connectors. This figure has merit of his own, so I'm sharing it in the meantime.

Print one copy of each plate - they are formatted for a 225 x 145 build platform.  Pop the pins into the appropriate holes.  Enjoy!  
Our springy friend stands about 16.5" tall, or 415mm.

This is a ball made out of three thin rings. The rings are connected by small hooks. It is light and springy - you won't break either this ball or something else by throwing this sphere around.
Fixed a few bugs in calculating thickness; done a thicker version.
ring-thicker.scad flies better a lot when printed out of ABS. 
I failed to upload STL because of timeouts - now I succeeded with 6-ring stl which allows you to assemble two spheres out of one print.

Step 1. Print three rings. You can print them separately, or print a stack of three rings at once. I print three rings at once on top of each other with dashed-line layers between rings.
Step 1a. If you printed three rings on top of each other, separate them using a knife. It is possible to separate them with pliers, or even by hand, but best results are obtained using a knife.
Step 2. Connect the rings. I suggest connecting two rings by using hooks on both of them (hook of the external ring holds the internal ring, hook of the internal ring holds the hook of the external ring). Note that you will have to bend the rings a little in the process.
Step 3. Optionally, you could glue or melt together the joints. Of course, if the joints disconnect, they usually do it one by one and you can easily repair your ball even if it is not glued.
Enjoy your ball!

title: E3d V6 Bowden Carriage with LJ18A3-8-ZBX Sensor

description.text:
Another carriage for Vulcanus Max (or other similar machines - lm10uu's distance 50mm center to center).

I use an Inductive Proximity Sensor LJ18A3-8-ZBX (it triggers 8mm from metal) and bowden setup so i designed this type of carriage. My goal was the proximity sensor to be as close as possible to the hotend and not hanging outsite of the carriage (30mm in the X plane).

For the assembly it needs 4 zipties, 5xM3 screws at the top, 2xM3 screws for the e3d custom mount and 4xM3 for the belt tension parts. Each belt of the CoreXY cinematics, can be tighten individually.

Solidworks and Stl files are available.
If you have any recommendations, leave a comment so we can improve it.

Version 1.2 uploaded
Fixed some issues after printing the parts myself. Download and use the files in the .rar

Last Update: 17/9/2016 21:30

title: Geodesic Dome 4V Connector for 3/4" PVC pipe

description.text:
Geodesic Dome Connector for 3/4" PVC pipe 4V

http://www.acidome.ru/lab/calc/#1/4_Piped_D50_4V_R2.186_beams_30x30

these hubs are for "equal chords" style Geodesic dome, since I only have geodesic dome generator that can generate "equal chords" type, which is the standard type.

could be re-scaled to fit any size pipe theoretically.
for 1/2" PVC pipe, re-scale to 73.5%
for 1" PVC pipe, re-scale to 129%

need to lay flat and print.

recommend #6 self drilling pan head screws for securing PVC pipes to these connectors.

Printer:

cheap chinese knock off

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

the shell thickness should be at least 3 mm, thicker is better obviously.

this connectors don't need support to print,
but other hubs do need support.

print one out, and try in with your pipe, and adjust scale accordingly,

because not all PVC manufacturers have exactly same dimensions.

cut the PVC pipe as perpendicularly as possible,

and use #6 self drilling pan head screw to secure it as shown.

description.text:
I had the need of an additional Nozzle Fan for PLA printing and TPU printing (slow small spikes) and remixed a cooler addon using ThinkerCad and Google Sketchup.

I also added a Plate for mounting your standard radial Fan front of the printhead using the 2 Screws from the both bearings of the X Axis. Didn't add any holes for the Fan himself, because i wanted to keep it compatible as possible for other fans.

Any Suggestions welcome.

Update 19.9.2016:

Adjusted the length of the Nozzle Cooler a bit. Now fits gently.

Update 24.10.2016:

Added another Nozzle cooler, who also cools the coldend ;)

author: scholarslab

print_settings.Notes:: Support is needed for the mounting lug.

description.text:
I created an apple picker consisting of a long wooden stick with a hinge at the end. The gripping jaws are the printed parts. These are half balls with a mounting lug that one can attach to the stick using the preprinted screw holes. The ball has a lot of holes in it to see through and to save material. Look at the pictures how the mechanism is made. I simply pull a rope at the other hand to close the jaws and grasp my apples.

I used a stick that measures 13x29mm. For your convenience I included the SCAD-file in which you can change the measures (within a certain range).

Obviously you need to print this part twice.

Note: The apple picker on the photographs is 1.2mm thick, but this seems to be a little too optimistic. After a few buckets of apples the thing was slightly damaged. Therefore I doubled the thickness in the STL and SCAD-file posted here.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Support is needed for the mounting lug.

title: Flashforge Creator Pro (FFCP) -> Diamond Hotend Upgrade

description.text:
These are all the parts I used to modify my flashforge creator pro (2016) to utilize the diamond hotend extruder. This is a MASSIVE modification that took me a few weeks. I've included all the SolidWorks files so that you can modify the parts if you want. This is a complex mod, and when you are done, you will have a totally new printer that only looks like a FFCP. You will need to be comfortable with soldering, flashing firmware, and figuring things out on the fly in order to complete this project. Expect to spend several days printing everything, and make sure you have everything figured out before you start the teardown process. All of the printed parts in this project are printable with a flashforge creator pro 2016 - but some just barely fit. You will probably have to play with the orientations to get them just right. That being said, it's TOTALLY WORTH IT! The improvement is huge in terms of performance, control, and configuration.

Modifications include:

1) Incorporation of an air scrubber to filter out ABS fumes
2) Replacing the stock MightBoard with a RUMBA (required to drive three extruders and mix colors, also HUGE improvement over stock performance)
3) Incorporation of three E3D bowden extruders
4) Replacement of the stock LCD/SD card assembly with the "Full Graphic Smart LCD Controller"
5) New housing for the replacement LCD
6) Mounting adapter to screw the RUMBA board in place of the MightyBoard

You will also need to buy a few other things:
1) Plastic screws (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GDXW0A6)
2) High static-pressure fan (https://www.amazon.com/Swellder-TFB0412EHN-cooling-40mmx28mm-control/dp/B00XDXR1XA)
3) Filters (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00COTZTJW/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s02)
4) Also get some weatherstripping from the hardware store, and use it to seal the extruder mount/scrubber assembly to your clear plastic hood. The stuff I got was grey, and you can see it squirting out of the scrubber mount in a few of the pictures I posted.
5) A stepper motor for the third extruder.
6) 3x E3D Titian Extruders
7) diamond hotend (http://www.reprap.me/diamond-hotend.html)

You also need to print these parts:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:899168
Make sure to print them in ABS, otherwise they will creep (melt and get saggy)

You should probably edit the RUMBA adapter plate part and shift it so that the USB port of the RUMBA board lines up with the USB hole in the frame. I was lazy and opted to just make an extension (see photo).

Also note that this will probably work on any of the replicator derivatives with some modification. I'll leave that up to you, though :)

more details to come soon!

author: quicktel

description.text:
Problem: window that can open but cannot be fixed when partially open.
Solution: measure your window, make your own holder.

Usually, there is something that holds the window when it is closed. You should measure all the wanted sizes of your optimal holder - it should nearly-tightly fit on the opening part, and its hook should align with the part you want to use as an anchor. Holder slides vertically, but horizontal shift has to be measured. Make sure the cut is wide enough to actually hold. 
I printed a few copies of various lengths to be able to have window half-open and one-third-open.

2016-12-23
Added a "Base_mid.stl" for those of you who wants more than 4 rolls. This part makes it possible to enlargen your stand by placing this part in the middle and then using rods that are 200mm long instead.

This idea came up when I ordered a set of four color 26AWG wires, 10 meters each, from a Chinese Ebay seller. I received the wires just as is without any spool or something to keep it nice and tidy (figures), so I went full on and designed a nice stand for it.

I made it capable of holding four spools of 26AWG wires, but hit me up on the comments and I'll make it compatible for other specs too.

The only hardware you need is three 5x100mm steel rods (just Ebay it for a small sum).

As it might be a bit of a hassle to manually tread all the wires onto these spools, I made a tiny pin that you can hook up to a drill or a screwdriver (check the pictures) and simply let it spin while threading the wire. Just print the Threading_bit.stl and Threading_pin.stl and use a M3x16-20 to attach it to one of the spools.

comments.text: Yes, I have seen similar designs with that spacer, but I think a simple metal washer maybe it's better, because is smoother. Thanks for the info, I'll put some in the final build.
comments.author: tigers75

comments.text:
I had exactly the same problem of the original maker, and came across this item; I am currently finishing building one (one spool still to print), and I have to say it's very brilliantly designed: the spool even has a notch in the inside to hold the cable while it's threaded. Without it's almost impossible to wind it up the spool.
Since this is one of my first prints I struggled a little with my printer settings to get a decent result on the spools (must set to maximum density to get it good looking and some warping problems with the lateral stands), and will post photos when I'm done.
Some little suggestions:
comments.author: tigers75

comments.text: Actually, due to the nature of FDM 3D-printing, making holes like that not only makes the print take longer time, but it uses more material, since it will need to print perimeters for all those holes.
comments.author: tigers75

comments.text:
You are probably right, I am new to 3D printing so forgive me...
The customization needs to be made only for the cable guide, and maybe to create a central stand, because I believe it would move too much with too many spoils.
Another development could be to make it double decked. That is 2 rows of spoils one on top of the other, so it takes up less space on the desk. This could be done maybe simply mirroring the lower part of the support.

Modeled to work with the Peak Design Capture and Capture Pro clips. This will snap in and slide out of the Capture systems just like their aluminum counterparts. If you use plastic, I do not recommend replacing the metal ones with this as they are much weaker. I have modified these to snap my headphones case, water bottle, and other small accessories to my camera bag. There is also a model that will fit most standard tripods as well.

Feel free to download and modify. If you do then please post! I would love to see what creative things people are using with the Capture system!

author: Myanc

description.text: This was just a quick model for a school project. I thought it turned out nice and maybe some one could use it for a Pathfinder or D&D prop.

Actually I don't have a stable relationship with anyone, but if in the future I find "the love of my life", and I decide to make a wedding proposal, something like this sure will be her wedding ring box.

Like the Nintendo SD cards holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1765326), this is a simple design where I re-used an official Mushroom Candy box for the Nintendo Shop of New York.

title: 47/37 gear set for approximate metric threads on Harrison L5 lathe

description.text:
A special remix of single gears to produce a 47 tooth and 37 tooth gear pair to enable metric threads to be approximated on a Harrison L5 lathe.

The configuration on a lathe is described well here:
http://www.lathe.com/metric_threading.htm#Diagram

If you need to tweak bore and keyway dimensions, you could use the customizer version this was derived from and print as two separate gears. Or you could download the SCAD files and make changes manually in OpenSCAD.

I haven't made one of these, and I don't need to because I have an original 127 tooth gear. If you make one please comment on your experience.

Update: Pushing the envelope a bit more - I have also worked up a design for a 3 piece jigsaw of a full sized 127T gear http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1802545 that is printable on a 200mm square bed. This can deliver exact metric pitch threads (provided you have the other gears required - 40T, 50T, 60T and 63T).

I wanted to get a good, sturdy headphone stand but add some additional flare while I was at it. So I made a Chaos worshiping headphone stand with chaos symbols, skulls for Khorne and space marine heads for Chaos Undivided.

The print came out quite well unfortunately the skulls were rather complex since they blended in and under the model I hadn't removed some unnecessary stuff so I recommend doing that to save some filament. The symbols also sagged a bit unfortunately as expected with the way the stand was oriented when printing. Perhaps dividing the piece up and printing it with a different orientation should solve this problem.

The print was also made smaller than intended, about 10% smaller in order to fit on the printing bed at University. My RAW Prism headset still fits comfortable on top and I have placed a laptop cord wrangler beneath so that it stays still and keeps my cord tidy :)

Windows 3D Builder

title: High-Tech Soda Can Cooler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
OK, I admit, it's just a piece of plastic, therefore ‘high tech’ may be a bit exaggerated.
Still, this is not your average soda can cooler, or ‘koozie’ as it is sometimes called. This one has no inner shell, instead it relies on the can itself to seal the air inside, to have a minimal contact area with the plastic, and instead rely maximally on air for insulation. Moreover, the walls are divided into horizontal compartments to reduce convection.

Whether all this really makes a difference in keeping your drink cool compared to simpler designs, I cannot guarantee. However, it certainly looks cool when printed in a semi-transparent material, and it is very light.
I tested the difference between a can inside this cooler compared to a bare can, both starting at 3°C in a room at 23°C. After one hour, the can in the cooler was at 10.4°C, the other one at 14.6°C. This was with the cooler starting out at room temperature. If you would refrigerate the koozie as well before using it, it would keep your drink cool for a slightly longer time.

Two models are provided, one for standard 330 ml cans, and one for 355 ml (12 US fl oz). The model assumes a standard diameter of 66.3 mm. If your favourite brand appears to have a slightly different diameter, scale accordingly to provide a tight fit. A full can should slowly slide into the cooler by itself (or with a slight push), but an empty can should not come out by itself when held upside down.

Because there are basically no solid volumes in this model, infill doesn't really matter.

author: squadzone

description.text:
This food pellet dispenser was developed by Dr. Andrew Maurer's Lab in the McKnight Brain Institute at the University of Florida.

The dispenser consists of four separate 3D printed components and uses a bipolar stepper motor to dispense individual 45mg food pellets.

An infrared break-beam attached to one of the external interrupt pins is used to keep track of how many pellets have been dispensed.

The dispenser is designed to be operated with an Arduino using an Adafruit motor driver shield (or any other micro-controller and H-bridge).

Part List
  • 4x - M3x0.5 hex nut (McMaster-Carr part number: 90695A033)
  • 2x - M3 35mm socket cap screw (McMaster-Carr part number: 92095A201)
  • 2x - M3 50mm socket cap screw (McMaster-Carr part number: 92095A475)
  • 1x - 3mm IR break-beam (Adafruit part number: 2167)
  • 1x - Adafruit Motor Shield v2 (Adafruit part number: 1438)
  • 1x - Nema 14 bipolar stepper motor (Pololu part number: 1208)
Code Examples

Break-beams are interrupt driven to keep track of the number of pellets dispensed. The Adafruit motor driver library was used to handle the motor control.

void beamBroken_isr(){
  noInterrupts();
  pells--;
  disp++;
  broken = true;
  Serial.println("Beam Broken");
  if(disp == 5){
    disp = 0;
    rot = !rot;
  }
  interrupts();
}

The dispenser is set to switch the direction of the rotor after every five steps. This was found to reduce jamming and crushed pellets. A delay of 100ms was added after each step to help the break-beams to detect individual pellets.

if (f == "disp" || f == "Disp") {
  pellsR = param;
  Serial.print("Dispensing ");
  Serial.print(param);
  Serial.println(" pellets");
  while(pells>0){
    if(rot == false){
      myMotor->step(25, FORWARD, SINGLE);
      delay(100);
    }
    else if(rot == true){
      myMotor->step(25, BACKWARD, SINGLE);
      delay(100);
    }
  }
}

Use drill diameter 5 mm for holes. For case use M4 screws and nuts.
For rotation the generator use one from pulleys. This depend on ratio Input DC motor:Output Generator.

Input DC motor is 3V/5V/12V DC motor, or a wind/water turbine. Output is this generator.
Generator include a rotor(9x 1cm cylinder/cube magnets,1cm length), bottom case, top case, 2 ball bearings, 9 screws(metal/plastic), 9 coils(with/without metal OD 5mm core), shaft(4mm screw + M4 nuts) and pulley.

Use 2 ball bearings OD=12.74 mm, ID=4.7mm, Height=5mm, (table milling tool)
Shaft is 4 mm screw and M4 nuts as needed. (Can be connect more generator on one shaft).

Coils are 9. So use from 1 to 9 coils, depend on output energy. Coils can be connected parallel or serial as needed. Wire for the coil is in a range 0.1 - 0.6 mm depend on ratio Voltage:Amperage. Material of the wire is a two layers enameled copper wire. So for contact on an end use sharp tools and soldering iron.

The component socket is what is different.  The old style had the metal runner on the drawer flush with the end of the drawer.  The new version has the drawer metal runner stick out and needs to be able to recess into the component socket.  I can whip up a new copy with the exact dimensions as the generation 2 of the case runner if you want, but I think that his will work.  The old version is a bit thinner in some spots, so a beefier version might be needed.  My originals are still working, but every component socket is broke.  Kids burn through these.  My new printable design has more beef to it.  So I hope it lasts longer.   NTC490 added some more beef to his here as well.  Ours are pretty close to the same.

remixed_from.author: GarzaDB
remixed_from.title: Left handed E3D Titan extruder upgrade for Prusa i3

title: Prusa i3 E3D Titan mount and fan duct

description.text:
This is an mount and fan duct for the E3D Titan extruder and its' included 5015 blower fan and a V6 hotend. This was made for the Prusa i3 Titan + V6 upgrade kit from E3D. Other hotends than V6 may be too long or short to properly align with the fan vent exhaust (haven't checked). It should fit all i3-based printer models with the regular i3 X-axis.

It is a remix of the left handed design by GarzaDB;

The carriage part has a few changes;

  • Removed the part sticking out on the top left
  • Removed the inductive sensor holder
  • Added a cable management loop on top
  • Made stepper motor holder thicker to add rigidness and durability

There is also a completely redesigned fan mount for the included blower fan. The fan is screwed down with two screws and the fan output nozzle fits inside a slot for easier mounting. The improvements and goals of this redesign compared to the original provided in GarzaDB's version are

  • Fan air is captured better
  • Fan output is all around the hotend nozzle area, below the block
  • Fan output is not limited by a small output hole
  • Sturdier mounting and more rigid
  • Prints without supports

The fan part is compatible with GarzaDB's carriage, so if you prefer that version with an inductive sensor holder, you can still use it with this fan mount (EDIT: I haven't tried this. Maybe it's not true, since the fan hood looks like it would obstruct the sensor).

Using the new E3D heater block sock is recommended. That's the blue thing around the heater block. It will insulate the heaterblock and nozzle from cooling air, and also insulate the printed fan vent from the heaterblock's heat. Also, it insulates your print from heat radiation coming from the heater block, allowing your print to cool better.

Notes:

I suggest printing the fan holder in ABS, I don't think PLA nor PETG will be able to handle the heat around the heater block good enough (but if the layer fan is always expected to be on, it could work I guess). Both parts print without supports.

Hardware - see picture!

Screws already in Prusa i3 Upgrade kit:
M3 x 25
M3 x 35

Extra screws needed:
M3 x 55
M3 x 20 and nut
M3 x 30 - this is optional, I don't use it. The titan's face plate keeps the parts in place, and I lower resistance turning the extruder gear without a screw here.
Please share your make if you print it :-)

title: Angel with missing hand -  Enscan-S Sample Scan

description.text:
This is a capture of an angel statue using the Einscan-S. This capture used the turn-table. It took 3 rotations, one standing up, one facing down and one facing up. No touchups were done to the resulting stl file. As you can see the result is not bad. Some loss of feather detail inside the wings but overall, not bad.

This is discussed with a lot more detail about the Einscan-S scanner in an upcoming episode of the 3D Printing Today podcast: threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com
